options.label: D

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of symbiosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A relationship between two species where one species benefits and the other is harmed.

options.label: B
options.text: A partnership between two different species where both species depend on each other.

options.label: C
options.text: A process where one species eats another species.

options.label: D
options.text: A relationship between two species where neither species benefits or is harmed.

multiple-choice.question: Where do whitebark pines primarily grow?

options.label: A
options.text: In the mountains of Wyoming, Montana, and other western states.

options.label: B
options.text: In the forests of the eastern United States.

options.label: C
options.text: In the deserts of the southwestern United States.

options.label: D
options.text: In the mountains of the southeastern United States.

multiple-choice.question: What do squirrels and other animals do with the whitebark pine cones?

options.label: A
options.text: They replant them in the forest.

options.label: B
options.text: They store them in their pouches.

options.label: C
options.text: They gnaw the cones from the upper branches so they fall to the ground.

options.label: D
options.text: They ignore the cones.

options.label: A
options.text: It is short and weak.

options.label: B
options.text: It is long and tough.

options.label: C
options.text: It is shaped like a hook.

options.label: D
options.text: It is covered in feathers.

multiple-choice.question: What do the Clark's nutcrackers do with the seeds they gather?

options.label: A
options.text: They eat them immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: They store them in their pouches and replant them in the forest.

options.label: C
options.text: They bury them in piles.

options.label: D
options.text: They give them to other animals.

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 10 seeds.

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 80 seeds.

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 90 seeds.

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 100 seeds.

multiple-choice.question: What do the Clark's nutcrackers use to remember the location of the seeds they cache?

options.label: A
options.text: Their sense of smell.

options.label: B
options.text: Their sense of sight.

options.label: C
options.text: Landmarks on the landscape.

options.label: D
options.text: Their sense of hearing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the symbiosis between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the nutcrackers benefit.

options.label: B
options.text: Only the whitebarks benefit.

options.label: C
options.text: Both species benefit.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither species benefits.

multiple-choice.question: How have the whitebark pines evolved to suit the needs of the Clark's nutcrackers?

options.label: A
options.text: Their branches have become shorter.

options.label: B
options.text: Their cones have become smaller.

options.label: C
options.text: Their branches all sweep upwards with the cones at the very ends.

options.label: D
options.text: Their leaves have become larger.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the Clark's nutcrackers not retrieving the seeds they cache?

options.label: A
options.text: The seeds rot and decay.

options.label: B
options.text: The seeds are eaten by other animals.

options.label: C
options.text: The seeds become whitebark pine trees.

options.label: D
options.text: The seeds are replanted in the forest.

options.label: B

options.label: B
